messageBody:
Yes, I imagine that all languages do have this. I intended my question
to be about the relative frequency. Teaching myself to write English
in QS has forced me to pay attention to the details of my own accent
as never before. I started thinking about more vowel-rich languages
such as Spanish. It seems to me (although I only studied the language
in school) that Spanish has less such modification. I started
wondering if the extent to which spoken languages contain
emphasis-driven changes in pronunciation is correlated with the
density of vowels in their phonological structure. My sample is too
small (and my analysis quite possibly dead wrong) for me to draw any
conclusions. I was just wondering if anyone knew of any existing
comparative studies.

Ted

On Sun, Sep 7, 2008 at 9:27 AM, Benct Philip Jonsson <bpj@...> wrote:
> Ted Larson Freeman skrev:
>
>> Is English an unusual language in this regard? I suppose ESL students
>> must be taught the subtle differences in emphasis in speech such as:
>> 1) What do YOU think?
>> 2) Wuh-duh-yuh think?
>> 3) D'yuh THINK?
>>
>> I can't remember any such instruction (ignoring elision in French) in
>> my foreign language classes. Was I simply not advanced enough for
>> this?
>>
>> Ted
>
> Surely all languages have this. In German _es geht_
> 'it works' is pronounced as _s'geht_ and there are other
> examples still. In Swedish _det_ 'it' and _det är_
> 'it is' are homophones [de:] and _för att_ 'in order to,
> because' is pronounced _f'rå_ [fro:] when it means
> 'in order to' and _f'ratt_ [frat] when it means 'because'
> and so on. In my adaptation of QS to Swedish this
> phenomenon is half-acknowledget since _det_ is
> abbreviated to 4 and _är_ is abbreviated to 31, so
> that the spelling of _det är_ becomes phonetic,
> and the words spelled _de_ and _dem_ 'they, them',
> which are both pronounced [dom] are abbreviated
> to the otherwise unused 8 (since Swedish has no [D]).
> Similarly _för_ 'for' is abbreviated to 9, the
> word _att_ when pronounced [o] is spelled with
> 36 directly joined to a half-3, while [at] is
> spelled with unjoined 36+3 -- these are really
> two different words which only happen to be
> spelled alike in Swedish Orthodox. In case
> you wonder the spelling 34 is used for the
> word _och_ 'and' which is also pronounced [o].
>
>> On Mon, Sep 1, 2008 at 12:19 PM, John Cowan <cowan@...> wrote:
>> <snip>
>>
>>> Indeed. There are many short English words that have both strong and
>>> weak pronunciations. For example, the words "him" and "her" have weak
>>> pronunciations without the "h" (this has nothing to do with h-dropping in
>>> certain accents; it is a universal feature of up-to-speed English
>>> speech).
>>> In the same way, the strong form of "you" has Ooze, whereas the weak form
>>> has Utter. No proposed orthography that I know of represents the weak
>>> form of any word other than "the", and why should it be an exception to
>>> the strong-only rule?
>>>
>>> --
>>> John Cowan <cowan@...> http://www.ccil.org/~cowan
>>> Charles li reis, nostre emperesdre magnes,
>>> Set anz totz pleinz ad ested in Espagnes.
>>>
>
